2352F.5 Criteria for risk acceptability including criteria for accepting risks when the
2353probability of occurrence of harm cannot be estimated
2354Criteria for risk acceptability are derived from the manufacturer's policy for determining acceptable risk
2355(see D.4). The criteria can be common for similar categories of medical device. Criteria for risk acceptability
2356can be part of the manufacturer’s established quality management system, which can be referenced in the risk
2357management plan (see for example ISO 13485:2003[8], 7.1).
2358F.6 Verification activities
2359The risk management plan will specify how the two distinct verification activities required by this International
2360Standard will be carried out (see also A.2.6.3). Verifying the effectiveness of risk control measures can require
2361the collection of clinical data, usability studies, etc. (see also 2.28) The risk management plan can detail the
2362verification activities explicitly or by reference to the plan for other verification activities.
2363F.7 Method or methods of obtaining relevant post-production information
2364The method or methods of obtaining post-production information can be part of established quality
2365management system procedures (see for example ISO 13485:2003[8], 8.2). Manufacturers should establish
2366generic procedures to collect information from various sources such as users, service personnel, training
2367personnel, incident reports and customer feedback. While a reference to the quality management system
2368procedures can suffice in most cases, any product-specific requirements should be directly added to the risk
2369management plan.
2370The risk management plan should include documentation of decisions, based on a risk analysis, about what
2371sort of post-market surveillance is appropriate for the device, for example, whether reactive surveillance is
2372adequate or whether proactive studies are needed. Details of clinical studies envisaged should be specified.

2384Annex G
2385(informative)

2387Information on risk management techniques
2388G.1 General
2389This annex provides guidance on some available techniques for risk analysis, which can be used under 4.3.
2390These techniques can be complementary and it might be necessary to use more than one of them. The basic
2391principle is that the chain of events is analysed step by step.
2392Preliminary Hazard Analysis (PHA) is a technique that can be used early in the development process to
2393identify the hazards, hazardous situations, and events that can cause harm when few of the details of the
2394medial device design are known.
2395Fault Tree Analysis (FTA) is especially useful in safety engineering, early in the development stages, for the
2396identification and prioritization of hazards and hazardous situations as well as for analysing adverse events.
2397Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA) and Failure Mode, Effects and Criticality Analysis (FMECA) are
2398techniques by which an effect or consequences of individual components are systematically identified and is
2399more appropriate as the design matures.
2400Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP) and Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point (HACCP) are typically
2401used in the latter stages of the development phase to verify and then optimize design concepts or changes.
2402G.2 Preliminary Hazard Analysis (PHA)
2403PHA is an inductive method of analysis with the objective of identifying the hazards, hazardous situations and
2404events that can cause harm for a given activity, facility or system. It is most commonly carried out early in the
2405development of a project when there is little information on design details or operating procedures and can
2406often be a precursor to further studies. It can be useful when analysing existing systems or prioritizing hazards
2407where circumstances prevent a more extensive technique from being used.
2408In a PHA, one formulates a list of hazards and generic hazardous situations by considering characteristics
2409such as:
2410a)
2411materials used or produced and their reactivity;
2412b)
2413equipment used;
2414c)
2415operating environment;
2416d)
2417layout;
2418e)
2419interfaces among system components.
2420The method is completed with the identification of the probabilities that the accident happens, the qualitative
2421evaluation of the extent of possible injury or damage to health that could result, and the identification of
2422possible remedial measures. The results obtained can be presented in different ways such as tables and trees.
2423See IEC 60300-3-9:1995[21], A.5, for more information on the procedures for PHA.

2434G.3 Fault Tree Analysis (FTA)
2435FTA is primarily a means of analysing hazards identified by other techniques and starts from a postulated
2436undesired consequence, also called a “top event.” In a deductive manner, starting with the top event, the
2437possible causes or fault modes of the next lower functional system level causing the undesired consequence
2438are identified. Following stepwise identification of undesirable system operation to successively lower system
2439levels will lead to the desired system level, which is usually either the component fault mode or the lowest
2440level at which risk control measures can be applied. This will reveal the combinations most likely to lead to the
2441postulated consequence. The results are represented pictorially in the form of a tree of fault modes. At each
2442level in the tree, combinations of fault modes are described with logical operators (AND, OR, etc.). The fault
2443modes identified in the tree can be events that are associated with hardware faults, human errors, or any
2444other pertinent event, which leads to the undesired event. They are not limited to the single-fault condition.
2445FTA allows a systematic approach, which, at the same time, is sufficiently flexible to allow analysis of a variety
2446of factors, including human interactions. FTA is used in risk analysis as a tool to provide an estimate of fault
2447probabilities and to identify single fault and common mode faults that result in hazardous situations. The
2448pictorial representation leads to an easy understanding of the system behaviour and the factors included, but,
2449as the trees become large, processing of fault trees can require computer systems, which are readily available.
2450See IEC 61025[28] for more information on the procedures for FTA.
2451G.4 Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA)
2452FMEA is a technique by which the consequences of an individual fault mode are systematically identified and
2453evaluated. It is an inductive technique using the question “What happens if ... ?”. Components are analysed
2454one at a time, thus generally looking at a single-fault condition. This is done in a “bottom-up” mode, i.e.,
2455following the procedure to the next higher functional system level.
2456The FMEA is not restricted to a failure of a component's design but can also include failures in the
2457manufacturing and assembling of components (Process FMEA) and the use or misuse of the product by the
2458end user (Application FMEA). FMEA can be extended to incorporate an investigation of the individual
2459component fault modes, their probability of occurrence and detectability (only to the degree that detection will
2460enable preventive measures in the context of this International Standard) and also the degree of severity of
2461the consequences. The FMEA can become a Failure Mode, Effects and Criticality Analysis (FMECA). In order
2462to perform such an analysis, the construction of the medical device should be known in some detail.
2463FMEA can also be a useful technique to deal with use error. Disadvantages of this technique can arise from
2464difficulties in dealing with redundancies and the incorporation of repair or preventive maintenance actions, as
2465well as its restriction on single-fault conditions.
2466See IEC 60812[27] for more information on the procedures for FMEA.
2467G.5 Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP)
2468HAZOP is similar to an FMEA. HAZOP is based on a theory that assumes accidents are caused by deviations
2469from the design or operating intentions. It is a systematic technique for identifying hazards and operability
2470problems. It was originally developed for use in the chemical process industry. While the use of HAZOP
2471studies in the chemical industry focuses on deviations from design intent, there are alternative applications for
2472a medical device developer. A HAZOP can be applied to the operation/function of the medical device (e.g., to
2473the existing methods/processes used for the diagnosis, treatment or alleviation of disease as the “design
2474intent”), or to a process used in the manufacture or maintenance/service of the medical device
2475(e.g., sterilization) that can have significant impact on the function of the medical device. Two particular
2476features of a HAZOP are as follows:
2477 it uses a team of people with expertise covering the design of the medical device and its application;
2478 guide words (NONE, PART OF, etc.) are used to help identify deviations from normal use.

2490The objectives of the technique are:
2491 to produce a full description of the medical device and how it is intended to be used;
2492 to review systematically every part of the intended use in order to discover how deviations from the
2493normal operating conditions and the intended design can occur;
2494 to identify the consequences of such deviations and to decide whether these consequences can lead to
2495hazards or operability problems.
2496When applied to the processes used to manufacture a medical device, the last objective is particularly useful
2497in those cases where the medical device characteristics depend upon the manufacturing process.
2498See IEC 61882[29] for more information on the procedures for HAZOP.
2499G.6 Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point (HACCP)
2500This is a systematic approach to the identification, evaluation and control of hazards. It was originally
2501developed by NASA to prevent food poisoning of astronauts. It is based on a set of principles and defined
2502terms. Applied to medical devices, HACCP is used for the control and monitoring of initiating causes of
2503product hazards originating in processes, particularly manufacturing processes.
2504The core curriculum of HACCP consists of the following seven principles:
25051
2506Conduct hazard analysis (4.3) and identify
2507preventive measures (6.2)
25082
2509Determine the critical control points (CCPs)
2510(6.2)
25113
2512Establish critical limits (4.2 and Clause 5)
25134
2514Monitor each CCP (6.3 and Clause 9)
25155
2516Establish corrective actions (Clause 9)
25176
2518Establish verification procedures (6.3 and
2519Clause 9)
25207
2521Establish record-keeping and documentation
2522procedures (3.5 and Clause 8)
2523 
2524Each product has its own hazards that are related to its intended use. Hazardous situations could be initiated
2525by events (causes or contributing factors) during different life-cycle stages, such as design, manufacturing,
2526service, use, disposal, etc. For examples of some types of hazard, see Annex E.
2527The heart of an effective HACCP system focuses on the continuing control and monitoring (HACCP
2528principles 2, 3 and 4), of the identified hazards. A manufacturer demonstrates the effectiveness of
2529established control measure(s), (HACCP principles 5 and 6), by establishing methodically documented
2530process mapping, process hazard analysis and critical control plan, (HACCP principle 7).
2531The HACCP system uses the following tools as documented evidence for record keeping:
2532a)
2533Process flow diagram
2534The purpose of the diagram is to provide a clear and simple description of the steps involved in the process.
2535The diagram is necessary to the HACCP team in its subsequent work. The diagram can also serve as a future
2536guide for others who need to understand the process for their verification activities. The scope of the flow
2537diagram should cover all the processing steps that are directly under the control of the manufacturer.
2538b) Hazard analysis worksheet
2539Hazard analysis is the identification of hazards and of their initiating causes. The analysis records contain:
25401)
2541the identification and listing of steps in the process where hazards of significance occur;
25422)
2543the listing of all identified hazards and their significance associated with each step;

2558c)

2560The written document is based upon the seven principles of HACCP and delineates the procedures to be

25621)
2563identifying critical control points and critical limits identification;
25642)
2565monitoring and continuing control activities;
25663)
2567identifying and monitoring corrective action, verification and record-keeping activities.

2579Annex H
2580(informative)

2582Guidance on risk management for in vitro diagnostic medical devices
2583H.1 General
2584This annex provides additional guidance on the application of risk management to in vitro diagnostic (IVD)
2585medical devices. It focuses on the management of risk to patients from the use of IVD examination results.
2586Examples used are intended to illustrate concepts and serve as a starting point for risk management of IVD
2587medical devices. They are not meant to be exhaustive. For definitions of terms used in this annex,
2588see ISO 18113-1 [42].
2589IVD medical devices are intended for use in the collection, preparation and examination of samples taken from
2590the human body. These devices include reagents, instruments, software, sample collection devices and
2591receptacles, calibrators, control materials and related accessories. These devices can be used alone or in
2592combination as a system.
2593Results provided by IVD medical devices can be used in the diagnosis of disease or other conditions,
2594including determination of the state of health, in order to cure, mitigate, treat or prevent disease, as well as
2595monitoring of therapeutic drugs and determining the safety of donated blood or organs. These devices can be
2596used by persons with various levels of education, training and experience and in different settings with various
2597degrees of environmental control. For example, some IVD medical devices are intended for use by
2598professional analysts in medical laboratories, others by healthcare providers at the point-of-care, and still
2599others by lay users at home.
2600At one end of the spectrum, IVD examinations performed in a laboratory are reported to a physician, who
2601interprets the data and diagnoses, treats or monitors a patient; at the other end, IVD examinations are
2602performed by the patient, who uses the results to monitor and medicate his/her condition.
2603Because of the diversity of IVD medical devices and their intended uses, these guidelines might not be
2604applicable in all cases. For IVD medical devices for self-testing, the terms “patient” and “lay user” will be used
2605interchangeably, even though these can be different individuals (e.g. a parent can perform glucose
2606measurements on a diabetic child). Where the term “physician” is used, it should be recognised that other
2607healthcare providers can also order, receive, interpret and act on IVD examination results.
2608IVD medical devices have the potential to contribute to patient harm. Incorrect or delayed results can lead to
2609inappropriate or delayed medical decisions and actions that result in harm to patients. Incorrect results from
2610IVD medical devices intended for transfusion or transplantation screening have the potential to cause harm to
2611blood or organ recipients, and incorrect results from IVD medical devices intended for detecting infectious
2612diseases have the potential to be a hazard to public health.
2613One risk model for IVD medical devices used in a laboratory is illustrated in Figure H.1. In this example, a
2614failure of the manufacturer’s quality system (e.g. during design, development, manufacturing, packaging,
2615labelling, distribution or servicing) initiates a sequence of events, beginning with a defective or malfunctioning
2616IVD medical device. When the device fails in the medical laboratory, an incorrect examination result is
2617produced. If the result is not identified as incorrect by the laboratory, it will be reported to the healthcare
2618provider. If the healthcare provider does not recognise the result as incorrect, it could adversely influence the
2619diagnosis and create a hazardous situation for the patient.

2631Figure H.1 — A risk model for laboratory use of IVD medical devices
2632Physicians use IVD examination results together with other available medical information to evaluate a patient
2633and reach a diagnosis or guide therapy. In some cases, the IVD result can be the primary or even the only
2634basis for a medical decision. The probability of a patient being harmed is a combination of the probabilities
2635that each event illustrated in Figure H.1 would occur. Each individual probability of occurrence is partially
2636offset by a probability that the hazard or hazardous situation will be detected by the manufacturer, the
2637laboratory or the physician, thus allowing intervention and avoiding harm. The actual sequence of events will
2638depend on the particular IVD medical device and its application.
2639Figure H.1 also shows that the laboratory can contribute to incorrect or delayed examination results, for
2640example as a consequence of failing to follow procedures, adhere to maintenance or calibration schedules, or
2641heed warnings or precautions. In addition, events leading to patient harm can also be initiated in the
2642laboratory. The need for reduction of errors through risk management in the medical laboratory has been
2643recognised, and information for safety as an output of the manufacturer’s risk management process could
2644serve as an input to the laboratory’s risk management process.
2645H.2 Risk analysis
2646H.2.1 Identification of intended uses
2647H.2.1.1
2648General
2649IVD medical devices for laboratory or point of care examinations have two users: (1) an operator who
2650performs the examination, and (2) a healthcare provider who receives, interprets and acts on the results. In
2651the case of IVD medical devices for self-testing, the patient could be the only user.
2652Identification of intended uses should consider the objective intent of the manufacturer with respect to both
2653elements of use: (1) use of the IVD medical device to produce an examination result, and (2) use of the
2654examination result to reach a decision on the diagnosis, treatment or monitoring of a patient.

2666In this annex, the following terms should be interpreted broadly:
2667 “Operator” means the individual performing the IVD examination; this individual can be a laboratory
2668worker, a healthcare provider or a lay person with minimal or no training;
2669 “Healthcare provider” means the individual ordering, receiving or acting upon the examination results on
2670behalf of a patient; this individual can be a physician, nurse, ambulance attendant or any other person
2671making a medical decision based upon IVD examination results.
2672H.2.1.2
2673Intended use
2674The intended use of an IVD medical device can include the measurement system, analyte, kind-of-property,
2675sample matrix, examination procedure (qualitative, semi-quantitative or quantitative), type of operator and site
2676of use.
2677For example, quantitative examinations for beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (E-hCG) concentration can be
2678ordered for serum, plasma or urine samples. Not every E-hCG examination procedure has performance
2679characteristics suitable for all three types of sample matrix.
2680H.2.1.3
2681Indications for use
2682The indications for use include the medical applications and patient populations for which the IVD medical
2683device is intended.
2684For example, E-hCG results can be used for detecting pregnancy, for screening pregnant women for foetal
2685Down's syndrome, and for monitoring certain cancers. Each medical application may have different
2686requirements for measurement sensitivity, specificity, precision and trueness.
2687H.2.2 Identification of possible use errors
2688H.2.2.1
2689Use errors
2690Use errors include actions not intended by the manufacturer, such as procedure shortcuts, optimization
2691attempts and improvization, as well as omissions of actions intended by the manufacturer, such as
2692those prescribed in the instructions for use.
2693H.2.2.2
2694Examples of possible use errors by laboratory personnel
2695The following are examples of possible use errors in the laboratory. These examples are intended to illustrate
2696the principles and are not an exhaustive checklist:
2697 use of an IVD medical device with an inappropriate calibrator, reagent, instrument or sample matrix;
2698 attempt to optimize an examination procedure in order to improve its performance characteristics;
2699 abbreviation of an examination procedure (taking “shortcuts”);
2700 neglect of instrument maintenance;
2701 disabling or failing to enable safety features;
2702 operation in adverse environmental conditions.

2713H.2.2.3
2714Examples of possible use errors by healthcare providers
2715The following are examples of possible use errors by a healthcare provider. These examples are intended to
2716illustrate the principles and are not an exhaustive checklist:
2717 use of IVD examination results in order to screen a population for a disease when the examination
2718procedure is intended for diagnosing the disease (the performance characteristics might not be
2719appropriate for population screening);
2720 use of IVD examination results in order to diagnose a disease when the examination procedure is
2721intended for monitoring a condition (the performance characteristics might not be appropriate for
2722diagnosis);
2723 use of IVD examination results for a new clinical application that is not claimed by the manufacturer (the
2724performance characteristics might not be appropriate for the new application).
2725H.2.2.4
2726Examples of possible use errors by patients in self-testing
2727The following are examples of possible use errors by a patient during self-testing. These examples are
2728intended to illustrate the principles and are not an exhaustive checklist:
2729 using insufficient volume of sample;
2730 failure to insert a reagent module properly;
2731 dividing reagent strips (e.g. to reduce cost);
2732 disabling or failing to enable safety features;
2733 storing reagent in inappropriate conditions.
2734H.2.3 Identification of characteristics related to safety
2735H.2.3.1
2736General
2737In addition to chemical, mechanical, electrical and biological characteristics in common with other medical
2738devices, IVD medical devices have performance characteristics that determine the accuracy of the
2739examination results. Failure to meet the performance characteristics required for a specific medical use could
2740result in a hazardous situation that should be evaluated for risk to patients.
2741H.2.3.2
2742Performance characteristics of quantitative examination procedures
2743Quantitative examination procedures are intended to determine the amount or concentration of an analyte.
2744Results are reported on an interval scale. The main analytical performance characteristics of quantitative
2745examination procedures are precision (imprecision), trueness (bias), analytical specificity and quantitation limit.
2746Performance requirements depend on the medical application. A falsely high or falsely low result can lead to
2747an incorrect diagnosis or delayed treatment, and the consequent harm to the patient could depend on the
2748concentration of analyte and magnitude of bias.
2749H.2.3.3
2750Performance characteristics of qualitative examination procedures
2751Qualitative examination procedures are only intended to detect the presence or absence of an analyte.
2752Results are reported as positive, negative or inconclusive. Performance of qualitative examination procedures
2753is generally expressed in terms of diagnostic sensitivity and specificity. A positive result when the analyte is
2754absent or a negative result when the analyte is present can lead to incorrect diagnosis or delayed treatment
2755and to harm to the patient.

2767H.2.3.4
2768Dependability characteristics
2769When physicians depend on IVD examination results to help make urgent medical decisions, such as in an
2770intensive critical care setting, timely results can be as important as accurate results. Failure to produce a
2771result when it is needed could result in a hazardous situation.
2772H.2.3.5
2773Ancillary patient information
2774In some cases, examination results can require demographic information about the patient, as well as
2775pertinent information about the sample or its examination for proper interpretation. Patient identification,
2776sample identification, sample type, sample description, measurement units, reference intervals, age, gender,
2777and genetic factors are examples of such information, which might be entered manually by a laboratory
2778analyst or automatically by a laboratory computer system. If an IVD medical device is designed to report
2779ancillary information with the examination result, failure to associate the correct information with the
2780examination result could affect the proper interpretation of the result and lead to a hazardous situation.
2781H.2.4 Identification of known and foreseeable hazards
2782H.2.4.1
2783Hazards to the patient
2784From the standpoint of a patient, an IVD examination result is a hazard if it might lead to (1) inappropriate
2785medical action that could result in injury or death, or (2) failure to take appropriate medical action that could
2786prevent injury or death. An incorrect or delayed IVD examination result can be caused by an IVD medical
2787device malfunction, which is the initiating hazard in a foreseeable sequence of events leading to a hazardous
2788situation. The identification of hazards and sequences of events are intended to help the manufacturer
2789compile a comprehensive list of hazardous situations. The manufacturer determines what is considered a
2790hazard during the risk analysis.
2791As illustrated in Figure H.1, a hazardous situation can occur if a healthcare provider receives an incorrect
2792result and acts upon it. A hazardous situation can also occur if a result is not available when it is needed. In
2793the case of devices for self-testing, a hazardous situation can occur when an incorrect result is obtained by a
2794patient, or a result is not available when it is needed.
2795For quantitative examination procedures, a result can be considered incorrect if the difference from a correct
2796value exceeds a limit based on clinical utility. The clinical significance of an incorrect result can depend on the
2797magnitude of the difference between the measured value and a correct value, as well as the physiological
2798status of the patient (e.g., hypoglycaemic or hyperglycaemic).
2799For qualitative examination procedures, in which only a positive or negative result is provided, (e.g., HIV and
2800pregnancy examinations), results are either correct or incorrect.
2801The following hazards could cause or contribute to misdiagnosis with the potential for harmful medical
2802intervention or delays:
2803 incorrect results (see H.2.3.2 and H.2.3.3);
2804 delayed results (see H.2.3.4);
2805 incorrect information accompanying the result (see H.2.3.5).
2806H.2.4.2
2807Relationship to performance characteristics
2808Failure to meet specifications for any of the performance characteristics related to safety (see H.2.3) should
2809be evaluated in order to determine if a hazardous situation could result.
2810Tools for analysing such hazards, such as Preliminary Hazard Analysis (PHA), Fault Tree Analysis (FTA),
2811Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA), and Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points (HACCP), are
2812described in Annex G.

2823H.2.4.3
2824Identifying hazards in fault conditions
2825Failure modes that can result in not meeting the performance characteristics required for medical use
2826(e.g., trueness, precision, specificity, etc.) should be considered when identifying IVD hazards in fault
2827conditions; e.g.,
2828 within-batch inhomogeneity;
2829 batch-to-batch inconsistency;
2830 non-traceable calibrator value;
2831 non-commutable calibrator;
2832 non-specificity (e.g., interfering factors);
2833 sample or reagent carryover;
2834 measurement imprecision (instrument-related);
2835 stability failures (storage, transportation, in-use).
2836Failure modes that can result in delayed results in urgent care situations should be considered when
2837identifying IVD hazards in fault conditions; e.g.,
2838 unstable reagent;
2839 hardware/software failure;
2840 packaging failure.
2841Failure modes that can result in incorrect patient information should be considered when identifying IVD
2842hazards in fault conditions; e.g.,
2843 incorrect patient name or identification number;
2844 incorrect birth date or age;
2845 incorrect gender.
2846H.2.4.4
2847Identifying hazards in normal use
2848Incorrect results can also occur in normal use, even when the IVD medical device meets the performance
2849characteristics claimed by the manufacturer. This could be due to the uncertainty of examination results, the
2850biological variability of patient samples, choice of a cut-off value or other factors. An incorrect result in normal
2851use could lead to a hazardous situation for an individual patient; e.g.,
2852 imperfect discrimination between positive and negative samples: qualitative examination procedures
2853typically exhibit inherent false negative and false positive rates, caused in part by uncertainties associated
2854with determination of a suitable cut-off value;
2855 uncertainty of measurement: state-of-the-art technology can limit the precision of quantitative IVD medical
2856devices, such as glucose monitoring systems described in ISO 15197[13]; if performance criteria only
2857require 95 % of the results to meet a specified limit based on medical utility, then up to 5 % of the
2858individual results are allowed to fall outside the limit;

2869 
2870 unexpected influence of other constituents (interfering factors) in the sample matrix: new drugs,
2871biochemical metabolites, heterophilic antibodies and sample preparation materials can affect the
2872performance characteristics of an IVD examination procedure;
2873 natural heterogeneity of the analyte: antibodies and other proteins in blood samples are mixtures of
2874different isoforms; published performance characteristics of an IVD examination procedure might not
2875apply to all components of the mixture.
2876H.2.4.5
2877Identifying hazardous situations
2878Examples of hazardous situations created by IVD medical devices include:
2879 a blood bank receives false negative HIV or HBsAg results when screening transfusion blood;
2880 a physician makes a diagnosis of liver disease based on liver function examination results that were
2881affected by bilirubin interference;
2882 a hypoglycaemic diabetic patient obtains falsely elevated blood glucose concentration measurements
2883from a self-monitoring device.
2884H.2.5 Estimation of risks to patients
2885H.2.5.1
2886General
2887Risk estimation is based on the severity and probability of harm from each identified hazardous situation
2888associated with the IVD medical device, in both normal and fault conditions.
2889In the case of an incorrect IVD examination result, key determinants are (a) the probability that the result will
2890be recognised as incorrect and (b) the probability that the result will lead to an adverse medical action.
2891For results that falsely indicate that medical intervention should not be taken (e.g., false negative results or
2892false “normal” results), assessment of risk should include (1) the prognosis of the condition left untreated, (2)
2893the possibility of diagnosing the condition by other means and (3) the implications for individuals other than
2894the patient (such as transmissibility of an infectious agent or a heritable condition, or exposure of a foetus to
2895hazardous substances).
2896For results that falsely indicate that medical intervention should be taken (e.g., false positive results or false
2897“abnormal” results), assessment of risk should consider (1) the potential harm of inappropriate treatment, (2)
2898the possibility of excluding the condition by other means and (3) the implications for others (such as
2899examination or treatment for exposure to an infectious agent, and counselling or treatment for a heritable
2900condition).
2901H.2.5.2
2902Estimating severity of harm
2903The medical use of an IVD examination result determines the potential harm that an incorrect result can cause
2904to a patient. The intended uses and possible misuses discussed in H.2.1 and H.2.2 should be considered.
2905Estimating the severity of harm requires an understanding of the medical use of the IVD examination results,
2906the analytical performance requirements for each application and the extent to which medical decisions are
2907based on IVD examination results. For this reason, qualified medical input to the risk estimation process is
2908essential.
2909H.2.5.3
2910Estimating probability of occurrence
2911As illustrated in Annex E, the probability that use of an IVD medical device will result in harm depends on the
2912cumulative probabilities associated with a series of events.

292267
2923For the case of an IVD medical device used in a laboratory, as outlined in Figure H.1, these probabilities
2924include:
2925 the probability that the IVD medical device will produce an incorrect result;
2926 the probability that the laboratory will fail to detect the result as incorrect and will report the incorrect
2927result;
2928 the probability that the physician will fail to recognise the result as incorrect and will be led to take (or not
2929take) action;
2930 the probability that the patient will be harmed by the physician's action or inaction.
2931Laboratories can recognise a result as incorrect for reasons such as:
2932 the quality control system identified a change in performance of the examination procedure;
2933 the value of the measured property is not compatible with life;
2934 the result exceeded a critical limit that required the examination result to be verified;
2935 the difference compared to the patient's previous result exceeded an expected or plausible amount.
2936When estimating the probability of occurrence, consider that not all laboratories have effective detection
2937systems that can prevent incorrect results from being reported.
2938Physicians can recognise a result as incorrect for reasons such as:
2939 the result is physiologically impossible;
2940 the result is inconsistent with the patient’s clinical status;
2941 the result is contradicted by other data.
2942Where IVD medical devices are used outside of the laboratory setting, adequate or effective detection
2943systems often do not exist. Lay users might not be aware that certain results are improbable. For such IVD
2944medical devices not used in a laboratory, the examples in this subclause should be modified by omitting the
2945events and probabilities that do not apply.
2946Sufficient data are rarely available to calculate quantitative estimates of the probabilities listed above. The
2947questions in H.2.5.4 could be helpful in developing qualitative or semi-quantitative estimates of the
2948probabilities. These questions relate primarily to laboratory-based IVD medical devices, but similar questions
2949can be developed for other types of IVD medical devices.
2950H.2.5.4
2951Points to consider in estimating risk to the patient
2952H.2.5.4.1
2953What is the possibility that an incorrect result would be generated by the IVD medical
2954device?
2955 In a likely fault mode?
2956 In normal use?
2957 In reasonably foreseeable misuse?

2969H.2.5.4.2
2970What is the possibility that the incorrect IVD examination result would be detected by a
2971user/laboratory?
2972 Are control materials provided with the IVD medical device?
2973 Are controls integrated into the device to detect the fault condition?
2974 How effective would the controls be in detecting the fault condition?
2975 Are there other quality assurance measures that might detect the incorrect result (e.g., critical value
2976system, plausibility checks)?
2977 Would error messages allow a user to correct the problem and obtain a valid examination result upon re-
2978examination? For example, the message "not enough blood" on an instrument for self-testing is intended
2979to prompt the user to repeat the examination.
2980 If the device is intended for laboratory use, do laboratories have effective systems for detecting such an
2981incorrect result?
2982H.2.5.4.3
2983What is the possibility that the incorrect IVD examination result would be detected by the
2984physician?
2985 Do current standards of medical practice require a confirmatory examination for this analyte?
2986 Is a confirmatory examination performed automatically by the laboratory following a positive screening
2987examination result?
2988 Is this type of incorrect result recognisable in the context of other results, signs, symptoms and the
2989patient's medical history?
2990 Do physicians routinely corroborate the results for this analyte by other means and question those results
2991that do not fit the clinical impression?
2992 Are there other plausibility checks for this analyte that would alert the physician to an error?
2993 Is the examination the sole basis for critical medical decisions? To what extent is the diagnosis based on
2994the examination result (i.e., how does the examination contribute to the medical decision)?
2995 Does the urgency of the situation require an immediate decision, without an opportunity to obtain
2996confirmatory data or corroborating information? Does the examination result lead directly to a medical
2997decision/treatment?
2998 Are alternative examinations available, such as in the central laboratory, if a point-of-care device were to
2999fail?
3000H.2.5.4.4
3001What is the possibility that a physician would act or fail to act on the result?
3002 Is the IVD medical device a major determinant of therapy for serious conditions, such as malignant
3003tumours or life-threatening infections?
3004 Is the IVD medical device intended for transfusion, transplant, or other medical use that could cause
3005transmission of disease to recipients?
3006 Is the IVD medical device intended to monitor a critical body function, so that error or delay could result in
3007the death or permanent impairment of a patient?

3018H.2.5.4.5
3019What is the possibility that a physician's action/inaction would cause or contribute to harm
3020to the patient?
3021 Is the action irreversible, such as surgical resection or abortion?
3022 To what extent is the action reversible?
3023 To what extent is the action likely to injure the patient?
3024 To what extent would failure to take action lead to death or injury?
3025 What physiological conditions would contribute to the possibility of harm?
3026H.2.5.4.6
3027What is the severity of the resulting harm?
3028 Death?
3029 Life-threatening injury?
3030 Reduction in life expectancy?
3031 Irreversible deterioration of the state of health?
3032 Permanent impairment?
3033 Permanent damage to a body function/structure?
3034 Injury requiring medical intervention to prevent serious harm?
3035 Reversible deterioration of the state of health?
3036 Minor physical injury?
3037 Temporary impairment not requiring medical intervention?
3038 Temporary discomfort?
3039H.2.5.5
3040Risk information for IVD medical devices
3041H.2.5.5.1
3042Adverse event databases
3043Medical device vigilance programs collect data from manufacturers and end-users that can include examples
3044of adverse effects from incorrect or delayed IVD examination results. Manufacturers can evaluate reports from
3045similar IVD medical devices for possible relevance to their own devices and to help identify previously
3046unrecognised hazards or relevant trends. Caution is necessary when drawing conclusions from individual
3047reports, however. The information in adverse event databases is unverified and individual reports can contain
3048incomplete, incorrect or misleading information.
3049H.2.5.5.2
3050Consensus survey
3051Consensus of medical experts has been used to classify the effect of incorrect glucose concentration values
3052on patients performing self-monitoring of diabetes mellitus. Parkes et al.[41] describe a systematic survey
3053approach to obtaining medical input on risk to patients. They constructed an “error grid”, modelled after the
3054graphical approach used by Clarke et al.[36]. The consensus method of Parkes et al.[41] can be applied to
3055other measurands.

3067H.2.5.5.3
3068Physician Interviews
3069A traditional method for obtaining medical input regarding patient risk is to interview practicing physicians and
3070determine (1) how they use the IVD examination results, (2) whether they could recognize incorrect results,
3071(3) what actions they would take given a specific result, and (4) what consequences an inappropriate medical
3072action might have. While more subjective than Parkes’ survey approach, an interview strategy can be
3073constructed to help elicit degrees of bias or imprecision that might place patients at risk.
3074H.3 Risk evaluation
3075The depth of a risk evaluation should be proportional to the severity of the potential harm. The risk of each
3076incorrect result identified as hazardous should be evaluated as described in D.3 and D.4.
3077H.4 Risk control
3078H.4.1 General
3079Severity of harm to the patient is determined by the medical intervention, or lack of intervention, triggered by
3080the IVD examination result. The ability of a manufacturer to affect the severity of harm depends on the
3081particular IVD examination.
3082If the medical intervention depends on the magnitude of the reported value, such as from examinations for the
3083concentration of glucose, electrolytes, therapeutic drugs and certain enzymes, the severity of harm might be
3084reduced by risk control measures aimed at limiting the degree of bias, imprecision or interference. If the result
3085is either positive or negative however, the severity of harm to the patient cannot be reduced by the
3086manufacturer.
3087Risks to the patient from incorrect IVD examination results are generally reduced by lowering the probability of
3088occurrence. Activities to reduce risks from incorrect results should be prioritized according to the hierarchy in
30896.2. For IVD medical devices:
3090a)
3091attempt to reduce the probability that an incorrect result will occur through inherent safety by design;
3092improvement in the relevant performance characteristics (for example, analytical or diagnostic specificity,
3093trueness or precision) could be necessary to ensure that results meet the medical requirements;
3094b)
3095if inherent safety by design is not practicable, then implement protective measures to reduce the
3096probability that an incorrect result will be reported to the physician or patient, preferably through detection
3097by the device itself or by quality control procedures provided with the device;
3098c)
3099if protective measures are not practicable, then provide users with information for safety, such as specific
3100instructions, warnings and other information necessary to avoid hazardous situations.
3101NOTE 1
3102Methods of detection intended to be implemented apart from the device, such as recommended quality control
3103testing by the laboratory or recommended confirmatory examinations to be ordered by the physician, are considered
3104information for safety, not protective measures.
3105NOTE 2
3106The minimum information to be supplied with an IVD medical device by a manufacturer is specified in
3107regulations and international standards. See H.4.2.4.

3118H.4.2 Option analysis
3119H.4.2.1
3120Inherent safety by design
3121If medical requirements are not being consistently met, perhaps the design of the IVD medical device can be
3122modified to avoid generating clinically incorrect results, for example by improving one or more of the following,
3123as appropriate:
3124 precision of the measuring system;
3125 trueness of the calibrator values;
3126 analytical specificity of IVD reagents (e.g. better antibody);
3127 detection limit or quantitation limit of the examination procedure;
3128 reliability of the instrument (e.g. prevention of spurious results);
3129 discrimination between positive and negative samples;
3130 automation of mistake-prone procedural steps;
3131 positive sample identification (e.g. bar-coding);
3132 ease of use (e.g., as identified by studies of human factors).
3133Similarly, perhaps the manufacturing process can be improved to avoid producing IVD medical devices that
3134generate clinically incorrect results (i.e., fail to meet medical requirements). Hazard Analysis and Critical
3135Control Points (HACCP, see G.6) can help identify steps in the manufacturing process to prevent
3136nonconforming product, such as:
3137 reagents with excessive lot-to-lot variability;
3138 instrument components that cause spurious results;
3139 calibrator values that exceed bias specifications;
3140 control materials, calibrators or reagents that fail to meet shelf-life claims.
3141H.4.2.2
3142Protective measures
3143If improving the design of the IVD medical device is not practicable, then perhaps additional controls can be
3144incorporated into the device to detect conditions that produce incorrect results; e.g.,
3145 sample integrity checks to detect unacceptable samples (e.g., hemolysed);
3146 removal of foam (if the sampling device has a liquid level sensor) or fibrin clots from the sample;
3147 on-board sensors and software checks to detect adverse system conditions (e.g., incorrect temperature,
3148spectrophotometer drift, plugged pipetting mechanism);
3149 built-in controls to detect calibrator, reagent or instrument failures;
3150 alarms, error messages or algorithms that suppress incorrect results;
3151 plausibility algorithms to identify improbable results.

3162 
3163If manufacturing process improvements are not practicable, then perhaps additional process controls or tighter
3164specifications could be needed to help prevent release of nonconforming product; e.g.,
3165 inspection of incoming materials against appropriate quality specifications;
3166 in-process performance tests to detect nonconforming components;
3167 reference materials to ensure metrological traceability of calibrators (see ISO 17511[15] and
3168ISO 18153[17]);
3169 performance characteristics related to user requirements;
3170 final release tests.
3171H.4.2.3
3172Information for safety
3173H.4.2.3.1
3174Performance characteristics
3175Laboratory directors and healthcare providers need to know the relevant performance characteristics in order
3176to determine if the IVD medical device is suitable for their use. This information is supplied by the
3177manufacturer. Reliable estimates of performance characteristics at recognised medical decision points
3178disclose residual risks and enable the proper interpretation of examination results; e.g.,
3179 analytical specificity (e.g., effects of interfering or cross-reacting substances);
3180 trueness (i.e., acceptable bias);
3181 precision;
3182 detection limit or quantitation limit;
3183 accuracy (combination of precision and trueness);
3184 diagnostic sensitivity (fraction of true positive results in patients with disease);
3185 diagnostic specificity (fraction of true negative results in patients without disease).
3186H.4.2.3.2
3187Information to prevent production of incorrect results
3188Instructions for use, procedural limitations and environmental specifications are necessary to help users
3189prevent incorrect (hazardous) results; e.g.,
3190 sample collection, storage and preparation requirements;
3191 known interfering substances;
3192 validated measuring interval;
3193 warnings about improper use that can contribute to incorrect results;
3194 limitations regarding specific patient populations;
3195 warnings about inappropriate clinical conditions or inappropriate sample types;
3196 proper cleaning methods;
3197 preventive maintenance procedures and maintenance intervals;
3198 reagent storage requirements and expiration date.

3209H.4.2.3.3
3210Information to enable detection of incorrect results
3211Additional instructions and recommendations can help reduce the likelihood that incorrect (hazardous) results
3212will be reported; e.g.,
3213 control procedures to detect conditions leading to incorrect results (see ISO 15198[14]);
3214 installation procedure to verify acceptable performance;
3215 system suitability guidelines to identify HPLC or GC column failures;
3216 confirmatory examination procedure based on a different measurement principle.
3217H.4.2.3.4
3218Training and user qualification
3219Training can be offered by the manufacturer to help avoid use errors.
3220Training materials suitable for continuing education programmes can be provided to IVD medical device users.
3221For some critical IVD medical devices (e.g., oral anticoagulation monitoring systems for home use), a formal
3222user qualification programme sponsored by the manufacturer could be appropriate (see ISO 17593[16]).
3223H.4.2.4
3224Prescribed information for safety
3225Requirements for information supplied by the manufacturer have been established by regulation in many
3226countries. These are prescribed risk controls that address possible use errors and other potential hazards
3227common to IVD medical devices. Conformance to applicable regulations and standards can be cited as
3228evidence that risks from specific use errors have been controlled, subject to verification of effectiveness
3229(see H.4.3).
3230Table H.1 contains examples of possible use errors and the corresponding information generally supplied by
3231the manufacturer to help users avoid them.
3232Table H.1 — Examples of possible use errors and labelling risk controls
3233Use error
3234Risk control
3235Non-calibrated instrument
3236Specified calibration interval
3237Reagents that have lost reactivity
3238Expiration date on reagent packaging
3239Inadequate equipment maintenance
3240Maintenance instructions
3241Mixing of incompatible reagent lots
3242Lot identification and instructions
3243Examination of non-commutable body fluids
3244Specification of suitable sample types
3245Incorrect sample preparation
3246Sample preparation instructions
3247Incorrect reagent storage
3248Storage requirements, including critical factors
3249(temperature, light, moisture, etc.)
3250Confusion of reporting units (e.g., mmol/l or mg/dl)
3251Units displayed or printed with each result
3252Improper instrument installation
3253Installation instructions; qualification procedure
3254Incorrect instrument operation

3270H.4.2.5
3271Warnings, precautions and limitations
3272Explicit warnings, instructions and contra-indications can be effective risk controls for professional use IVD
3273medical devices as long as the consequences of failing to heed them are adequately disclosed or are obvious.
3274A statement that does not indicate a hazardous consequence of ignoring an instruction might not be an
3275effective risk control.
3276For example, an IVD medical device might be intended to examine plasma or serum samples, but not urine. If
3277the instructions for use are silent with respect to urine samples, some laboratories may use the device to
3278examine urine samples, particularly if state-of-the-art IVD medical devices are capable of examining urine
3279samples. Without an indication that the procedure will not perform satisfactorily with urine samples,
3280examination of such samples would be a foreseeable use error.
3281Similarly, examination results can be used for medical applications that were not intended by the manufacturer
3282and might not be appropriate for that IVD medical device. The manufacturer should evaluate the risks from
3283such applications, taking into consideration factors such as experience with similar devices, similar
3284circumstances of use for other devices, and the likelihood of such use. A manufacturer might need to provide
3285users with appropriate warnings, precautions and limitations to reduce the risks.
3286H.4.2.6
3287IVD medical device standards
3288International standards, national standards, regulations and regulatory guidance documents are available for
3289some types of IVD medical devices. Adherence to recognised product standards, regulatory requirements and
3290guidelines that address inherent safety, protective measures and information for safety could be used to
3291define requirements for design and testing, and conformance can be cited as evidence of risk control; for
3292example, ISO 15197[13], ISO 17593[16], ISO 19001[18] and ISO 18113-1 [42].
3293H.4.3 Verifying risk control effectiveness
3294The implementation and effectiveness of risk control measures – including information for safety – require
3295verification. The degree of verification depends on the risk being controlled.
3296For risks where the severity or the probability of occurrence of harm is low, a review of complaint files can be
3297sufficient verification. Where appropriate, this verification should include a prospective review of available
3298information for IVD medical devices with similar risk controls. For risks where the severity or the probability of
3299occurrence of harm is high, a prospective study might be needed to verify the effectiveness of the risk controls.
3300For example, a human factors study can assess the extent of user comprehension and compliance with
3301warnings and instructions and verify the effectiveness of the information supplied for safety. This can include
3302human factors such as print size, reading level, properly highlighted warning information, etc.
3303Assumptions about the effectiveness of information for safety should be made with caution. The following
3304limitations should be considered when estimating the reduction in risk resulting from specific information
3305supplied by the manufacturer.
3306 Laboratory accreditation requirements, regulations and enforcement are not uniform throughout the world;
3307quality control and quality assurance practices vary widely.
3308 Instructions for use provided with professional use IVD medical devices are intended for medical
3309laboratories; information about contra-indicated uses, interfering drugs, and other information pertaining
3310to the use of IVD examination results might not reach the physicians who order the examinations.

3321H.5 Production and post-production monitoring
3322H.5.1 External performance monitoring
3323IVD manufacturers generally have access to external data that can be used to monitor some aspects of IVD
3324medical device performance; for example, as applicable:
3325 adverse event reports;
3326 complaints regarding incorrect results, misidentified samples, instrument dependability, etc.;
3327 intra-laboratory quality control data;
3328 External Quality Assessment Schemes (EQAS), also called proficiency surveys;
3329 performance evaluations performed by independent laboratories, often published in the scientific literature.
3330H.5.2 Internal performance monitoring
3331Manufacturers also routinely generate data that can be used to monitor certain performance characteristics in
3332controlled conditions. These sources include:
3333 process monitoring;
3334 stability monitoring;
3335 calibrator value assignments;
3336 acceptance testing;
3337 equipment reliability testing;
3338 validation activities.

3350Annex I
3351(informative)
3352 
3353Guidance on risk analysis process for biological hazards
3354I.1 General
3355This annex provides guidance on the application of risk analysis, with respect to biological hazards. The range
3356of effects of potential biological hazards is wide and can include short-term effects such as acute toxicity,
3357irritation to the skin, eye and mucosal surfaces, hemolysis and thrombogenicity, as well as long-term or
3358specific toxic effects such as subchronic and chronic toxic effects, sensitization, genotoxicity, carcinogenicity
3359(tumorigenicity) and effects on reproduction including teratogenicity.
3360ISO 10993-1[5] sets out the general principles for the biological evaluation of materials/medical devices.
3361I.2 Estimation of biological risks
3362I.2.1 Factors to be taken into account
3363The biological risk analysis should take account of:
3364 the physical and chemical characteristics of the various choices of materials;
3365 any history of clinical use or human exposure data;
3366 any existing toxicology and other biological safety data on product and component materials;
3367 test procedures.
3368The amount of data required and the depth of the investigation will vary with the intended use and are
3369dependent upon the nature and duration of patient contact. Data requirements are usually less stringent for
3370packaging materials, medical devices contacting intact skin, and any component of a medical device that does
3371not come into direct contact with body tissues, infusible liquids, mucous membranes or compromised skin.
3372Current knowledge of the material/medical device provided by scientific literature, previous clinical experience,
3373and other relevant data should be reviewed to establish any need for additional data. In some cases, it can
3374become necessary to obtain formulation data, residue data (e.g. from sterilization processes, monomers),
3375biological test data, etc.
3376I.2.2 Chemical nature of the materials
3377Information characterizing the chemical identity and biological response of materials is useful in assessing a
3378medical device for its intended use. Some factors that can affect the biocompatibility of the material include:
3379 the identity, concentration, availability and toxicity of all constituents (e.g. additives, processing aids,
3380monomers, catalysts, reaction products);
3381 the influence of biodegradation and corrosion on the material.
3382Where reactive or hazardous ingredients have been used in, or can be formed by, the production, processing,
3383storage or degradation of a material, the possibility of exposure to residues should be considered. Information

3394on residue concentration or leaching can be necessary. This can take the form of experimental data or
3395information on the chemistry of the materials involved.
3396Where the necessary data (e.g. complete formulation data) are not available to a manufacturer because of
3397confidentiality, verification should be obtained that an assessment has been carried out, of the suitability of the
3398material for use in the proposed application.
3399I.2.3 Prior use
3400Available information on previous uses of each material or intended additive and on any adverse reactions
3401encountered should be reviewed. However, the previous use of an ingredient or material does not necessarily
3402assure its suitability in similar applications. Account should be taken of the intended use, the concentration of
3403the ingredients, and current toxicological information.
3404I.2.4 Biological safety test data
3405ISO 10993-1[5] gives guidance on which tests in the ISO 10993 series should be considered for a particular
3406application. The need for testing should be reviewed on a case-by-case basis in the light of existing data, so
3407that unnecessary testing is avoided.

3420(informative)

3422Information for safety and information about residual risk
3423J.1 General
3424The purpose of this annex is to provide guidance on how:
3425 information for safety [see 6.2 c) and D.5.1 c)] can be a risk control measure and
3426 residual risk(s) can be disclosed (see 6.4 and Clause 7)
3427in such a way as to control risks and promote risk awareness.
3428Information for safety is the least preferred method of risk control, to be used only when other risk control
3429measures have been exhausted. Information for safety gives instructions on action(s) to take or not to take to
3430avoid a risk.
3431Disclosure of individual and overall residual risk(s) gives background and relevant information necessary to
3432explain the residual risk so users can proactively take appropriate actions to minimize exposure to the residual
3433risk(s).
3434It should be recognised that both the structure and contents of the information as well as the implementation
3435methods might need to be taken into consideration.
3436It should be recognised that information for safety, in particular, might need to be communicated in different
3437ways, depending on when in the medical device life-cycle the information is to be communicated, e.g. as
3438cautionary statements in the accompanying documents or in an advisory notice, or via the user interface of a
3439menu driven device.
3440J.2 Information for safety
3441When developing information for safety it is important to identify to whom this information is to be provided
3442and how it is to be provided. The manufacturer should provide an explanation of the risk, the consequences of
3443exposure and what should be done or avoided to prevent harm.
3444In developing the information, the manufacturer should consider:
3445 the level of priority appropriate to classify an action (danger, warning, caution, note, etc.);
3446 the level or detail of information needed;
3447 the location for the information for safety (e.g. a warning label);
3448 the wording or pictures to be used to ensure clarity and understandability;
3449 the immediate recipients (e.g. users, service personnel, installers, patients);
3450 the appropriate media for providing the information, (e.g. instructions for use, labels, alarms, warnings in
3451the user interface);
3452 regulatory requirements, etc.

3463J.3 Disclosure of residual risk(s)
3464When developing the disclosure of individual or overall residual risk(s) it is important to identify what is to be
3465communicated and to whom this is directed in order to inform, motivate and enable the user to use the device
3466safely and effectively. The manufacturer should examine the residual risk(s) identified in 6.4 and Clause 7 to
3467determine what should be disclosed.
3468The manufacturer should consider:
3469 the level or detail needed;
3470 the wording to be used to ensure clarity and understandability;
3471 the immediate recipients (e.g. users, service personnel, installers, patients);
3472 the means/media to be used.

EN ISO 14971:2012 (E)
16
5. Discretion as to the risk control options/measures:

a) 6.2 of ISO 14971 obliges the manufacturer to "use one or more of the following risk control options
in the priority order listed: (a) inherent safety by design; (b) protective measures in the medical device
itself or in the manufacturing process; (c) information for safety" and leaves a discretion as to the
application of these three options: shall the second or third control option still be used when the first
was used? 6.4 indicates that further risk control measures do not need to be taken if, after applying
one of the control options, the risk is judged acceptable according to the criteria of the risk
management plan.
b) However, the second sentence of Section A.2 of Annex I to Directive 98/79/EC requests "to
conform to safety principles, taking account of the generally acknowledged state of the art" and "to
select the most appropriate solutions" by applying cumulatively what has been called "control options"
or "control mechanisms" in the standard.
c) Accordingly, the manufacturer must apply all the "control options" and may not stop his endeavours
if the first or the second control option has reduced the risk to an "acceptable level" (unless the
additional control option(s) do(es) not improve the safety).

6. Deviation as to the first risk control option:

a) 6.2 of ISO 14971 obliges the manufacturer to "use one or more of the following risk control options
in the priority order listed: (a) inherent safety by design …" without determining what is meant by this
term.
b) However, the first indent of the second sentence of Section A.2 of Annex I to Directive 98/79/EC
requires to "eliminate or reduce risks as far as possible (inherently safe design and construction)".
c) Accordingly, as the Directive is more precise than the standard, manufacturers must apply the
former and cannot rely purely on the application of the standard.

7. Information of the users influencing the residual risk:

a) The residual risk is in 2.15 and in 6.4 of ISO 14971 defined as the risk remaining after application of
the risk control measures. 6.2 of ISO 14971 regards "information for safety" to be a control option.
b) However, the last indent of Section A.2 of Annex I to Directive 98/79/EC says that users shall be
informed about the residual risks. This indicates that, according to Annex I to Directive 98/79/EC and
contrary to the concept of the standard, the information given to the users does not reduce the
(residual) risk any further.
c) Accordingly, manufacturers shall not attribute any additional risk reduction to the information given
to the users.


Conformity assessment procedures

EN ISO 14971 can also be used to support the following parts of conformity assessment procedures in
the European Medical Devices Directives:

−
an adequate description of results of the risk analysis (included in the risk management file, see
3.5 of EN ISO 14971:2012);

−
an undertaking by the manufacturer to institute and keep up to date a systematic procedure to
review experience gained from devices in the post-production phase and to implement appropriate
means to apply any necessary corrective action (see Clause 9 of EN ISO 14971:2012).

NOTE
Other and more detailed requirements are applicable to this aspect.



WARNING — Other requirements and other EU Directives may be applicable to a product
falling within the scope of this standard.

v
Introduction
The requirements contained in this International Standard provide manufacturers with a framework within
which experience, insight and judgment are applied systematically to manage the risks associated with the
use of medical devices.
This International Standard was developed specifically for medical device/system manufacturers using
established principles of risk management. For other manufacturers, e.g., in other healthcare industries, this
International Standard could be used as informative guidance in developing and maintaining a risk
management system and process.
This International Standard deals with processes for managing risks, primarily to the patient, but also to the
operator, other persons, other equipment and the environment.
As a general concept, activities in which an individual, organization or government is involved can expose
those or other stakeholders to hazards which can cause loss of or damage to something they value. Risk
management is a complex subject because each stakeholder places a different value on the probability of
harm occurring and its severity.
It is accepted that the concept of risk has two components:
a)
the probability of occurrence of harm;
b)
the consequences of that harm, that is, how severe it might be.
The concepts of risk management are particularly important in relation to medical devices because of the
variety of stakeholders including medical practitioners, the organizations providing health care, governments,
industry, patients and members of the public.
All stakeholders need to understand that the use of a medical device entails some degree of risk. The
acceptability of a risk to a stakeholder is influenced by the components listed above and by the stakeholder’s
perception of the risk. Each stakeholder’s perception of the risk can vary greatly depending upon their cultural
background, the socio-economic and educational background of the society concerned, the actual and
perceived state of health of the patient, and many other factors. The way a risk is perceived also takes into
account, for example, whether exposure to the hazard seems to be involuntary, avoidable, from a man-made
source, due to negligence, arising from a poorly understood cause, or directed at a vulnerable group within
society. The decision to use a medical device in the context of a particular clinical procedure requires the
residual risks to be balanced against the anticipated benefits of the procedure. Such judgments should take
into account the intended use, performance and risks associated with the medical device, as well as the risks
and benefits associated with the clinical procedure or the circumstances of use. Some of these judgments can
be made only by a qualified medical practitioner with knowledge of the state of health of an individual patient
or the patient’s own opinion.
As one of the stakeholders, the manufacturer makes judgments relating to safety of a medical device,
including the acceptability of risks, taking into account the generally accepted state of the art, in order to
determine the suitability of a medical device to be placed on the market for its intended use. This International
Standard specifies a process through which the manufacturer of a medical device can identify hazards
associated with a medical device, estimate and evaluate the risks associated with these hazards, control
these risks, and monitor the effectiveness of that control.
For any particular medical device, other International Standards could require the application of specific
methods for managing risk.

INTERNATIONAL STANDARD
ISO 14971:2007(E)

© ISO 2007 – All rights reserved
1
Medical devices — Application of risk management to medical
devices
1
Scope
This International Standard specifies a process for a manufacturer to identify the hazards associated with
medical devices, including in vitro diagnostic (IVD) medical devices, to estimate and evaluate the associated
risks, to control these risks, and to monitor the effectiveness of the controls.
The requirements of this International Standard are applicable to all stages of the life-cycle of a medical
device.
This International Standard does not apply to clinical decision making.
This International Standard does not specify acceptable risk levels.
This International Standard does not require that the manufacturer have a quality management system in
place. However, risk management can be an integral part of a quality management system.
2
Terms and definitions
For the purposes of this document, the following terms and definitions apply:
2.1
accompanying document
document accompanying a medical device and containing information for those accountable for the
installation, use and maintenance of the medical device, the operator or the user, particularly regarding safety
NOTE
Adapted from IEC 60601-1:2005, definition 3.4.
2.2
harm
physical injury or damage to the health of people, or damage to property or the environment
[ISO/IEC Guide 51:1999, definition 3.3]
2.3
hazard
potential source of harm
[ISO/IEC Guide 51:1999, definition 3.5]
2.4
hazardous situation
circumstance in which people, property, or the environment are exposed to one or more hazard(s)
[ISO/IEC Guide 51:1999, definition 3.6]
NOTE
See Annex E for an explanation of the relationship between “hazard” and “hazardous situation”.

2
© ISO 2007 – All rights reserved

2.5
intended use
intended purpose
use for which a product, process or service is intended according to the specifications, instructions and
information provided by the manufacturer
2.6
in vitro diagnostic medical device
IVD medical device
medical device intended by the manufacturer for the examination of specimens derived from the human body
to provide information for diagnostic, monitoring or compatibility purposes
EXAMPLES
Reagents, calibrators, specimen collection and storage devices, control materials and related instruments,
apparatus or articles.
NOTE 1
Can be used alone or in combination with accessories or other medical devices.
NOTE 2
Adapted from ISO 18113-1:—, definition 3.29.
2.7
life-cycle
all phases in the life of a medical device, from the initial conception to final decommissioning and disposal
2.8
manufacturer
natural or legal person with responsibility for the design, manufacture, packaging, or labelling of a medical
device, assembling a system, or adapting a medical device before it is placed on the market or put into service,
regardless of whether these operations are carried out by that person or on that person's behalf by a third
party
NOTE 1
Attention is drawn to the fact that the provisions of national or regional regulations can apply to the definition of
manufacturer.
NOTE 2
For a definition of labelling, see ISO 13485:2003, definition 3.6.
2.9
medical device
any instrument, apparatus, implement, machine, appliance, implant, in vitro reagent or calibrator, software,
material or other similar or related article, intended by the manufacturer to be used, alone or in combination,
for human beings for one or more of the specific purpose(s) of
 diagnosis, prevention, monitoring, treatment or alleviation of disease,
 diagnosis, monitoring, treatment, alleviation of or compensation for an injury,
 investigation, replacement, modification, or support of the anatomy or of a physiological process,
 supporting or sustaining life,
 control of conception,
 disinfection of medical devices,
 providing information for medical purposes by means of in vitro examination of specimens derived from
the human body,
and which does not achieve its primary intended action in or on the human body by pharmacological,
immunological or metabolic means, but which may be assisted in its function by such means
NOTE 1
This definition has been developed by the Global Harmonization Task Force (GHTF). See bibliographic
reference [38].
[ISO 13485:2003, definition 3.7]

3
NOTE 2
Products, which could be considered to be medical devices in some jurisdictions but for which there is not yet
a harmonized approach, are:

aids for disabled/handicapped people,

devices for the treatment/diagnosis of diseases and injuries in animals,

accessories for medical devices (see Note 3),

disinfection substances,

devices incorporating animal and human tissues which can meet the requirements of the above definition but are
subject to different controls.
NOTE 3
Accessories intended specifically by manufacturers to be used together with a “parent” medical device to
enable that medical device to achieve its intended purpose, should be subject to this International Standard.
2.10
objective evidence
data supporting the existence or verity of something
NOTE
Objective evidence can be obtained through observation, measurement, testing or other means.
[ISO 9000:2005, definition 3.8.1]
2.11
post-production
part of the life-cycle of the product after the design has been completed and the medical device has been
manufactured
EXAMPLES
transportation,
storage,
installation,
product
use,
maintenance,
repair,
product
changes,
decommissioning and disposal.
2.12
procedure
specified way to carry out an activity or a process
[ISO 9000:2005, definition 3.4.5]
2.13
process
set of interrelated or interacting activities which transforms inputs into outputs
[ISO 9000:2005, definition 3.4.1]
2.14
record
document stating results achieved or providing evidence of activities performed
[ISO 9000:2005, definition 3.7.6]
2.15
residual risk
risk remaining after risk control measures have been taken
NOTE 1
Adapted from ISO/IEC Guide 51:1999, definition 3.9.
NOTE 2
ISO/IEC Guide 51:1999, definition 3.9 uses the term “protective measures” rather than “risk control
measures.” However, in the context of this International Standard, “protective measures” are only one option for controlling
risk as described in 6.2.

ISO 14971:2007(E)
4
© ISO 2007 – All rights reserved

2.16
risk
combination of the probability of occurrence of harm and the severity of that harm
[ISO/IEC Guide 51:1999, definition 3.2]
2.17
risk analysis
systematic use of available information to identify hazards and to estimate the risk
[ISO/IEC Guide 51:1999, definition 3.10]
NOTE
Risk analysis includes examination of different sequences of events that can produce hazardous situations
and harm. See Annex E.
2.18
risk assessment
overall process comprising a risk analysis and a risk evaluation
[ISO/IEC Guide 51:1999, definition 3.12]
2.19
risk control
process in which decisions are made and measures implemented by which risks are reduced to, or
maintained within, specified levels
2.20
risk estimation
process used to assign values to the probability of occurrence of harm and the severity of that harm
2.21
risk evaluation
process of comparing the estimated risk against given risk criteria to determine the acceptability of the risk
2.22
risk management
systematic application of management policies, procedures and practices to the tasks of analysing, evaluating,
controlling and monitoring risk
2.23
risk management file
set of records and other documents that are produced by risk management
2.24
safety
freedom from unacceptable risk
[ISO/IEC Guide 51:1999, definition 3.1]
2.25
severity
measure of the possible consequences of a hazard
2.26
top management
person or group of people who direct(s) and control(s) a manufacturer at the highest level
NOTE
Adapted from ISO 9000:2005, definition 3.2.7.

2.27
use error
act or omission of an act that results in a different medical device response than intended by the manufacturer
or expected by the user
NOTE 1
Use error includes slips, lapses and mistakes.
NOTE 2
See also IEC 62366:—, Annexes B and D.1.3.
NOTE 3
An unexpected physiological response of the patient is not by itself considered use error.
[IEC 62366:— 2), definition 2.12]
2.28
verification
confirmation, through the provision of objective evidence, that specified requirements have been fulfilled
NOTE 1
The term “verified” is used to designate the corresponding status.
NOTE 2
Confirmation can comprise activities such as:

performing alternative calculations;

comparing a new design specification with a similar proven design specification;

undertaking tests and demonstrations;

reviewing documents prior to issue.
[ISO 9000:2005, definition 3.8.4]
